{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3426145,"name":"Zachary 3838","username":"zach22","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/51bf81/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-09-22T20:14:56.040Z","cooked":"

i need code to make this robot move with a ir remote

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-09-22T20:14:56.040Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":38,"reads":153,"readers_count":152,"score":220.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":471664,"topic_slug":"can-you-run-a-frc-robot-with-a-jaguar-speed-controller-with-a-ardunio-with-a-ir-remote","display_username":"Zachary 3838","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68031,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-you-run-a-frc-robot-with-a-jaguar-speed-controller-with-a-ardunio-with-a-ir-remote/471664/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3426151,"name":"Ari Meles-Braverman","username":"AriMB","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arimb/{size}/189989_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-22T20:51:54.535Z","cooked":"

Just to clarify: You have an FRC robot with Jaguar motor controllers whose control system you want to replace with an Arduino. And instead of a driver station you want to use an IR remote control.

First off, you can use an Arduino to control Jaguar motor controllers over PWM. The Arduino can output PWM signals; look at the Servo library.

You’ll obviously need to recode the whole robot in Arduino language (C). If the robot just drives and has simple manipulators that might not be too bad. If it has complicated control systems then you may run into the limits of what the Arduino is capable of.

I’m not sure an IR remote is the best choice here, as it generally requires line-of-sight with the receiver. You might be better off looking at a bluetooth transmitter or a standard RC controller which (as I understand) use 2.4GHz radios.

Edit: And I assume you know this, but this setup wouldn’t be legal for an FRC competition

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2024-09-22T20:56:47.233Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":150,"readers_count":149,"score":75.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":471664,"topic_slug":"can-you-run-a-frc-robot-with-a-jaguar-speed-controller-with-a-ardunio-with-a-ir-remote","display_username":"Ari Meles-Braverman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-run-a-frc-robot-with-a-jaguar-speed-controller-with-a-ardunio-with-a-ir-remote/471664/2","custom_user_title":"FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3426180,"name":"Jason Brett","username":"dtengineering","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dtengineering/{size}/65392_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-22T21:41:27.102Z","cooked":"

I have a ride-on demo bot (people sit on it and drive it using a handheld joystick) powered by four CIMs controlled by four Victor 888 speed controllers connected to an Arduino Uno. I used the Arduino Servo library, as mentioned above.

In addition to dealing with code issues you may also need to deal with brown-out issues for the Arduino. If you have a modern FRC power distribution panel as part of the robot, then you’ll be able to check out the manual for the PDP to find out which ports will provide a steady voltage supply to the Arduino even when the motors draw very high currents causing the battery voltage to drop low. If you are building from scratch, though, you may want to look into buck/boost voltage regulators, or consider using a 3.3V microcontroller to reduce the risk of brown outs.

As for the code, start by studying the servo library and controlling a servo (you can do this virtually, online in TinkerCAD’s Arduino Simulations). Once you have that worked out you’ll need an IR receiver to pick up the remote control code. There are several excellent tutorials online that can walk you through this process. About 10-20 years ago I used the Sony IR remote protocol with my students for controlling mini sumo sized robots. Learning about the protocol is an enlightening experience.

If you aren’t tied to using IR, there is a neat Android app called “Remote XY” that allows you to use bluetooth or wifi modules with your Arduino (or other microcontroller) to control a device from your phone.

So YES… it can definitely be done, and by developing the code you will learning interesting concepts and enhance your programming and electronics skills. Good luck, and have fun!
